intro: Virola elongata var. longicuspis, commonly known as the long-toothed virola, is a member of the Myristicaceae family and is native to the tropical regions of South America. It is a deciduous tree that can grow up to 30 meters tall, characterized by its smooth, gray bark and large, elliptical leaves. The plant produces fragrant, yellowish flowers that are clustered in terminal panicles, followed by woody, spiky capsules containing numerous seeds. Its botanical significance lies in its unique morphology and potential ecological roles in its native habitats.
